constructors.doc: Creates a new widget using the specified area to layout cells inside the icons.
constructors.name: new_with_area

constructors.doc: Creates a new widget with the model model.
constructors.name: new_with_model

doc:
provides an alternative view on a . It displays the model as a grid of icons with labels. Like , it allows to select one or multiple items (depending on the selection mode, see ). In addition to selection with the arrow keys, supports rubberband selection, which is controlled by dragging the pointer.

Note that if the tree model is backed by an actual tree store (as opposed to a flat list where the mapping to icons is obvious), will only display the first level of the tree and ignore the tree’s branches.

methods.doc: Converts widget coordinates to coordinates for the bin_window, as expected by e.g. .
methods.name: convert_widget_to_bin_window_coords

methods.doc: Creates a #cairo_surface_t representation of the item at path. This image is used for a drag icon.
methods.name: create_drag_icon

methods.doc: Turns icon_view into a drop destination for automatic DND. Calling this method sets to false.
methods.name: enable_model_drag_dest

methods.doc: Turns icon_view into a drag source for automatic DND. Calling this method sets to false.
methods.name: enable_model_drag_source

methods.doc: Gets the setting set by .
methods.name: get_activate_on_single_click

methods.doc:
Fills the bounding rectangle in widget coordinates for the cell specified by path and cell. If cell is null the main cell area is used.

This function is only valid if icon_view is realized.
methods.name: get_cell_rect

methods.doc: Returns the value of the ::column-spacing property.
methods.name: get_column_spacing

methods.doc: Returns the value of the ::columns property.
methods.name: get_columns

methods.doc:
Fills in path and cell with the current cursor path and cell. If the cursor isn’t currently set, then path will be null. If no cell currently has focus, then cell will be null.

The returned must be freed with .
methods.name: get_cursor

methods.doc: Determines the destination item for a given position.
methods.name: get_dest_item_at_pos

methods.doc: Gets information about the item that is highlighted for feedback.
methods.name: get_drag_dest_item

methods.doc: Finds the path at the point (x, y), relative to bin_window coordinates. In contrast to , this function also obtains the cell at the specified position. The returned path should be freed with . See for converting widget coordinates to bin_window coordinates.
methods.name: get_item_at_pos

methods.doc: Gets the column in which the item path is currently displayed. Column numbers start at 0.
methods.name: get_item_column

methods.doc: Returns the value of the ::item-orientation property which determines whether the labels are drawn beside the icons instead of below.
methods.name: get_item_orientation

methods.doc: Returns the value of the ::item-padding property.
methods.name: get_item_padding

methods.doc: Gets the row in which the item path is currently displayed. Row numbers start at 0.
methods.name: get_item_row

methods.doc: Returns the value of the ::item-width property.
methods.name: get_item_width

methods.doc: Returns the value of the ::margin property.
methods.name: get_margin

methods.doc: Returns the column with markup text for icon_view.
methods.name: get_markup_column

methods.doc: Returns the model the is based on. Returns null if the model is unset.
methods.name: get_model

methods.doc: Finds the path at the point (x, y), relative to bin_window coordinates. See , if you are also interested in the cell at the specified position. See for converting widget coordinates to bin_window coordinates.
methods.name: get_path_at_pos

methods.doc: Returns the column with pixbufs for icon_view.
methods.name: get_pixbuf_column

methods.doc: Retrieves whether the user can reorder the list via drag-and-drop. See .
methods.name: get_reorderable

methods.doc: Returns the value of the ::row-spacing property.
methods.name: get_row_spacing

methods.doc:
Creates a list of paths of all selected items. Additionally, if you are planning on modifying the model after calling this function, you may want to convert the returned list into a list of #GtkTreeRowReferences. To do this, you can use .

To free the return value, use: |[<!-- language="C" --> g_list_free_full (list, (GDestroyNotify) gtk_tree_path_free); ]|
methods.name: get_selected_items

methods.doc: Gets the selection mode of the icon_view.
methods.name: get_selection_mode

methods.doc: Returns the value of the ::spacing property.
methods.name: get_spacing

methods.doc: Returns the column with text for icon_view.
methods.name: get_text_column

methods.doc: Returns the column of icon_view’s model which is being used for displaying tooltips on icon_view’s rows.
methods.name: get_tooltip_column

methods.doc:
This function is supposed to be used in a signal handler for . The x, y and keyboard_tip values which are received in the signal handler, should be passed to this function without modification.

The return value indicates whether there is an icon view item at the given coordinates (true) or not (false) for mouse tooltips. For keyboard tooltips the item returned will be the cursor item. When true, then any of model, path and iter which have been provided will be set to point to that row and the corresponding model. x and y will always be converted to be relative to icon_view’s bin_window if @keyboard_tooltip is false.
methods.name: get_tooltip_context

methods.doc:
Sets start_path and end_path to be the first and last visible path. Note that there may be invisible paths in between.

Both paths should be freed with after use.
methods.name: get_visible_range

methods.doc: Activates the item determined by path.
methods.name: item_activated

methods.doc: Returns true if the icon pointed to by path is currently selected. If path does not point to a valid location, false is returned.
methods.name: path_is_selected

methods.doc:
Moves the alignments of icon_view to the position specified by path. row_align determines where the row is placed, and col_align determines where @column is placed. Both are expected to be between 0.0 and 1.0. 0.0 means left/top alignment, 1.0 means right/bottom alignment, 0.5 means center.

If use_align is false, then the alignment arguments are ignored, and the tree does the minimum amount of work to scroll the item onto the screen. This means that the item will be scrolled to the edge closest to its current position. If the item is currently visible on the screen, nothing is done.

This function only works if the model is set, and path is a valid row on the model. If the model changes before the icon_view is realized, the centered path will be modified to reflect this change.
methods.name: scroll_to_path

methods.doc: Selects all the icons. icon_view must has its selection mode set to #GTK_SELECTION_MULTIPLE.
methods.name: select_all

methods.doc: Selects the row at path.
methods.name: select_path

methods.doc: Calls a function for each selected icon. Note that the model or selection cannot be modified from within this function.
methods.name: selected_foreach

methods.doc: Causes the signal to be emitted on a single click instead of a double click.
methods.name: set_activate_on_single_click

methods.doc: Sets the ::column-spacing property which specifies the space which is inserted between the columns of the icon view.
methods.name: set_column_spacing

methods.doc: Sets the ::columns property which determines in how many columns the icons are arranged. If columns is -1, the number of columns will be chosen automatically to fill the available area.
methods.name: set_columns

methods.doc:
Sets the current keyboard focus to be at path, and selects it. This is useful when you want to focus the user’s attention on a particular item. If cell is not null, then focus is given to the cell specified by it. Additionally, if start_editing is true, then editing should be started in the specified cell.

This function is often followed by gtk_widget_grab_focus (icon_view) in order to give keyboard focus to the widget. Please note that editing can only happen when the widget is realized.
methods.name: set_cursor

methods.doc: Sets the item that is highlighted for feedback.
methods.name: set_drag_dest_item

methods.doc: Sets the ::item-orientation property which determines whether the labels are drawn beside the icons instead of below.
methods.name: set_item_orientation

methods.doc: Sets the property which specifies the padding around each of the icon view’s items.
methods.name: set_item_padding

methods.doc: Sets the ::item-width property which specifies the width to use for each item. If it is set to -1, the icon view will automatically determine a suitable item size.
methods.name: set_item_width

methods.doc: Sets the ::margin property which specifies the space which is inserted at the top, bottom, left and right of the icon view.
methods.name: set_margin

methods.doc: Sets the column with markup information for icon_view to be column. The markup column must be of type #G_TYPE_STRING. If the markup column is set to something, it overrides the text column set by .
methods.name: set_markup_column

methods.doc: Sets the model for a . If the icon_view already has a model set, it will remove it before setting the new model. If model is null, then it will unset the old model.
methods.name: set_model

methods.doc: Sets the column with pixbufs for icon_view to be column. The pixbuf column must be of type #GDK_TYPE_PIXBUF
methods.name: set_pixbuf_column

methods.doc:
This function is a convenience function to allow you to reorder models that support the and the . Both and support these. If reorderable is true, then the user can reorder the model by dragging and dropping rows. The developer can listen to these changes by connecting to the model's row_inserted and row_deleted signals. The reordering is implemented by setting up the icon view as a drag source and destination. Therefore, drag and drop can not be used in a reorderable view for any other purpose.

This function does not give you any degree of control over the order -- any reordering is allowed. If more control is needed, you should probably handle drag and drop manually.
methods.name: set_reorderable

methods.doc: Sets the ::row-spacing property which specifies the space which is inserted between the rows of the icon view.
methods.name: set_row_spacing

methods.doc: Sets the selection mode of the icon_view.
methods.name: set_selection_mode

methods.doc: Sets the ::spacing property which specifies the space which is inserted between the cells (i.e. the icon and the text) of an item.
methods.name: set_spacing

methods.doc: Sets the column with text for icon_view to be column. The text column must be of type #G_TYPE_STRING.
methods.name: set_text_column

methods.doc:
Sets the tip area of tooltip to the area which cell occupies in the item pointed to by path. See also .

See also for a simpler alternative.
methods.name: set_tooltip_cell

methods.doc:
If you only plan to have simple (text-only) tooltips on full items, you can use this function to have handle these automatically for you. column should be set to the column in icon_view’s model containing the tooltip texts, or -1 to disable this feature.

When enabled, will be set to true and icon_view will connect a signal handler.

Note that the signal handler sets the text with , so &, <, etc have to be escaped in the text.
methods.name: set_tooltip_column

methods.doc: Sets the tip area of tooltip to be the area covered by the item at path. See also for a simpler alternative. See also .
methods.name: set_tooltip_item

methods.doc: Unselects all the icons.
methods.name: unselect_all

methods.doc: Unselects the row at path.
methods.name: unselect_path

methods.doc: Undoes the effect of . Calling this method sets to false.
methods.name: unset_model_drag_dest

methods.doc: Undoes the effect of . Calling this method sets to false.
methods.name: unset_model_drag_source

name: IconView

properties.doc: The activate-on-single-click property specifies whether the "item-activated" signal will be emitted after a single click.
properties.name: activate-on-single-click

properties.doc:
The used to layout cell renderers for this view.

If no area is specified when creating the icon view with a will be used.
properties.name: cell-area

properties.doc: The column-spacing property specifies the space which is inserted between the columns of the icon view.
properties.name: column-spacing

properties.doc: The columns property contains the number of the columns in which the items should be displayed. If it is -1, the number of columns will be chosen automatically to fill the available area.
properties.name: columns

properties.doc: The item-orientation property specifies how the cells (i.e. the icon and the text) of the item are positioned relative to each other.
properties.name: item-orientation

properties.doc: The item-padding property specifies the padding around each of the icon view's item.
properties.name: item-padding

properties.doc: The item-width property specifies the width to use for each item. If it is set to -1, the icon view will automatically determine a suitable item size.
properties.name: item-width

properties.doc: The margin property specifies the space which is inserted at the edges of the icon view.
properties.name: margin

properties.doc: The ::markup-column property contains the number of the model column containing markup information to be displayed. The markup column must be of type #G_TYPE_STRING. If this property and the :text-column property are both set to column numbers, it overrides the text column. If both are set to -1, no texts are displayed.
properties.name: markup-column

properties.doc: The ::pixbuf-column property contains the number of the model column containing the pixbufs which are displayed. The pixbuf column must be of type #GDK_TYPE_PIXBUF. Setting this property to -1 turns off the display of pixbufs.
properties.name: pixbuf-column

properties.doc: The reorderable property specifies if the items can be reordered by DND.
properties.name: reorderable

properties.doc: The row-spacing property specifies the space which is inserted between the rows of the icon view.
properties.name: row-spacing

properties.doc: The ::selection-mode property specifies the selection mode of icon view. If the mode is #GTK_SELECTION_MULTIPLE, rubberband selection is enabled, for the other modes, only keyboard selection is possible.
properties.name: selection-mode

properties.doc: The spacing property specifies the space which is inserted between the cells (i.e. the icon and the text) of an item.
properties.name: spacing

properties.doc: The ::text-column property contains the number of the model column containing the texts which are displayed. The text column must be of type #G_TYPE_STRING. If this property and the :markup-column property are both set to -1, no texts are displayed.
properties.name: text-column

signals.doc:
A [keybinding signal][GtkBindingSignal] which gets emitted when the user activates the currently focused item.

Applications should not connect to it, but may emit it with GObject.signal_emit_by_name if they need to control activation programmatically.

The default bindings for this signal are Space, Return and Enter.
signals.name: activate-cursor-item

signals.doc: The ::item-activated signal is emitted when the method is called, when the user double clicks an item with the "activate-on-single-click" property set to false, or when the user single clicks an item when the "activate-on-single-click" property set to true. It is also emitted when a non-editable item is selected and one of the keys: Space, Return or Enter is pressed.
signals.name: item-activated

signals.doc:
The ::move-cursor signal is a [keybinding signal][GtkBindingSignal] which gets emitted when the user initiates a cursor movement.

Applications should not connect to it, but may emit it with GObject.signal_emit_by_name if they need to control the cursor programmatically.

The default bindings for this signal include - Arrow keys which move by individual steps - Home/End keys which move to the first/last item - PageUp/PageDown which move by "pages" All of these will extend the selection when combined with the Shift modifier.
signals.name: move-cursor

signals.doc:
A [keybinding signal][GtkBindingSignal] which gets emitted when the user selects all items.

Applications should not connect to it, but may emit it with GObject.signal_emit_by_name if they need to control selection programmatically.

The default binding for this signal is Ctrl-a.
signals.name: select-all

signals.doc:
A [keybinding signal][GtkBindingSignal] which gets emitted when the user selects the item that is currently focused.

Applications should not connect to it, but may emit it with GObject.signal_emit_by_name if they need to control selection programmatically.

There is no default binding for this signal.
signals.name: select-cursor-item

signals.doc: The ::selection-changed signal is emitted when the selection (i.e. the set of selected items) changes.
signals.name: selection-changed

signals.doc:
A [keybinding signal][GtkBindingSignal] which gets emitted when the user toggles whether the currently focused item is selected or not. The exact effect of this depend on the selection mode.

Applications should not connect to it, but may emit it with GObject.signal_emit_by_name if they need to control selection programmatically.

There is no default binding for this signal is Ctrl-Space.
signals.name: toggle-cursor-item

signals.doc:
A [keybinding signal][GtkBindingSignal] which gets emitted when the user unselects all items.

Applications should not connect to it, but may emit it with GObject.signal_emit_by_name if they need to control selection programmatically.

The default binding for this signal is Ctrl-Shift-a.
signals.name: unselect-all

vfuncs.doc: Selects all the icons. icon_view must has its selection mode set to #GTK_SELECTION_MULTIPLE.
vfuncs.name: select_all
